title: Thursday, 10th May, 2018

You see I have personal experience on this front.

When you move from Western Europe to a big US city you expect a place like, say, New York to be much like the place you have come from in terms of ethics and culture.

pancakes or waffles Unrelated, but I thought the Big Read on Hong Kong tycoons was interesting
PM11:02am

But it's not.

Soundbuy Morgen
11:02 am
PM11:02am

New York, for instance, is much more like an African capital than a European one.

PM11:03am

In fact, when I first moved there with the kids one of them noted that it felt like Maputo -- skyscrapers and yellow cabs.

PM11:03am

And in New York you have to bribe people all the time.

11:03 am
PM11:03am

One example

PM11:04am

In my first week there I bought a bloody great Sony TV off Craigs List. From some Aussie lawyer who was fleeing the country.

PM11:04am

That involved paying a driver to transport the thing and then having to slip him another $20 to actually get the thing into the lobby of the apartment building.

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Then the Super tells me I can't transport the TV in the regular lift and so I have to bribe him another $20 to use the service lift.

JuB hi guys, could you please confirm where the Inmarsat bid spec started yesterday ? i.e. source ? I see it was in the FT wrap today ... just wondering if there is a source of the spec yesterday if poss
PM11:05am

And then you discover that there's a guy who actually lives in the service lift and you have to give that guy $20 to actually use the lift.

PM11:05am

And so it goes on. Living in New York you bribe people every day.

11:05 am
PM11:05am

Even school teachers in NYC expect to be bribed. They set up things like 'Holiday Funds" to cash all the checks for parents who don't have bundles of cash to hand.

PM11:05am

So I completely understand Novaritis' position. They just assumed that's how the place works.

PM11:06am

Still, entertaining for the rest of us.

Mouselet What would have happened if the Bank of England had left interest rates at 5% in 2008?
AAAA damn PM !!! what a story ! That's why i rather prefer living in Africa, it's cheaper !

BE11:17am

BT reported mixed 4Q18. Revenue of £5.97bn was 1.3% below
company consensus and EBITDA of £2.08bn broadly in line. Capex at £844m was below consensus, at £9.3bn, resulting in a 24% FCF beat.

Paper Chase No Baradar?
BE11:17am

BT is guiding FY19 EBITDA in the range of £7.3-7.4bn, 2-3% below consensus at £7.5bn. The company expects group revenue to fall by 2.0% (vs. a flat yoy from cons) due to 1) de-prioritizing low margin sales; 2) tough regulation headwinds. Capex to stay at £3.7bn for FY19 and FY20, compared to cons at £3.5-3.6bn. This reflects higher investments in networks and capacity, although the 10m FTTP target by mid-2020s was kept unchanged. BT guides to payout a flat DPS at 15.4p for the next two years vs. consensus of 15.68/15.92p, respectively.

11:17 am
BE11:18am

BT has reached an agreement with pension trusties valuing funding deficit at £11.3bn with contribution of £2.1bn to be made until FY20 (£850m in FY18, £0m in FY19 and £1.25bn in FY20). In addition, BT will issue long-term bonds to the BTPS totaling £2.0bn. Whilst the bond issue will not have immediate cash impact, it will negatively impact group net debt (excl. pension assets). Post FY20, BT will make payment of around £900m annually until FY30

BE11:19am

(@Paper Chase: nope, don't have Baradar this morning. GDPR might've silenced him, if Mifid II didn't. We'll try to address that asap.)

JuB ha Baradar is sadly out of the market
BE11:19am

The silver lining here is the newly announced restructuring plan,
which could lead to a £1.5bn cost savings in three years’ time. And the decision of keeping dividend unchanged means the stock will trade at an attractive yield at c7%. However, the disappointing guidance and higher-than-expected pension contributions mean material consensus downgrades post results. Until consensus settles and DCMS review results are out in summer 2018, we maintain our Neutral rating on the stock.

nichoman London - like a star collapsing in on itself and creating a giant black hole
Paper Chase @BE Aw, shame. But thanks.
11:19 am
BE11:20am

SocGen retains the faith.

pancakes or waffles @nichoman - poetic ;)
BE11:20am

There’s a lot to digest from BT today. Results are solid in our view, but 2019 guidance is weaker than expected due to increased regulatory headwinds at Openreach. However, we now have clarity on BT’s major issues and on medium-term numbers. We already knew that content was cheaper than expected, and now we know the pension has cost less too. Guidance today also suggests that fibre will raise capex by more than consensus expects, but if it pushes BT faster to the 10m FttH, then it will lower competitive and regulatory risks and will eventually provide a return, and that would be a good thing in our view. Savings then come through from 2020. After all is said and done, even if we have to swallow a hit to EBITDA and cash flow, we can now say that we have clarity – i.e. the dividend is safe, consensus is fully-loaded and the shares look genuinely cheap (8.1x PE, 7.2% cash yield and 6.8% dividend yield to March 2019) - so we believe we’re through the worst.

BE11:21am

Worth noting also that the strategy update's proving a bit jargon heavy and detail light.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

BE11:21am

[W]e are not seeing much of an update on some of the important issues. There are no new fibre targets and the dividend policy was reiterated, but the payout looks stretched if investments step up. The new Chairman was very complimentary about the work of BT’s CEO. We think the shares will continued to be weighed down until there is more clarity about investments, dividend (evidence that it is sustainable or reset), regulation and execution on the new strategy.

New initiatives announced today appear to represent self-help measures that reinforce existing strategy rather than taking BT in a bolder new direction. Altnet overbuilds threaten to chronically erode Openreach's wholesale BB market share, and weaken the prospect of Ofcom feeling the need to reach a 'fair bet' regulatory settlement with BT on full fibre. Against this backdrop, we have advocated BT accelerating its FTTP deployment ambitions without delay. Today's update is therefore a missed opportunity, in our view, setting prospects for more radical action back 12 months.

ITV has made a decent start to the year, with advertising benefiting from the timing of Easter being in Q1 and phasing in the notoriously lumpy Studios business helping that division to 9% organic growth in the period. Overall, revenues were up 5%. Given the low multiples at which ITV currently trades, it is not surprising that the market has taken these figures reasonably positively, but we stay cautious.

While Q1 is solid, Q2 is unlikely to look as good. The aforementioned lumpiness in Studios will mean growth for H1 is likely to be considerably slower than in Q1, while, despite the benefit of the World Cup, ITV is guiding to Q2 being slightly down in net advertising revenue (NAR) terms, for a flat H1 NAR outcome overall. Although this is a bit better than our most recent media buyer update, it is worse than at the start of the year.

risk reward at c150p. We see upside to EPS from capital allocation. Finally our work on
Discovery and Liberty suggests that they are credible bidders on strategic grounds and
have the financial firepower limiting downside risk. Liberty’s sale of European Cable
assets for EUR19bn gives the company renewed firepower to make complementary
acquisitions. Liberty already owns 9.9% of ITV’s capital.

BE11:46am

Superdry 4Q group revenues of £254.4m (+12.4%) are slightly  our estimates (£258m) owing to softer than expected retail channel growth predominantly in physical
stores, but also some moderation in e-commerce channels, and partially offset by better than expected wholesale revenues (6% above our estimate). The quarter was impacted by snow disruption and unseasonable weather in a Spring/Summer selling period, which contributed to some of the softness.
FY18E gross margin guidance is lower than previously (-200bps vs -170bps previously) due to negative channel mix and planned markdowns, whilst FY18 PBT guidance of £96.5m to £97.5m is 1.5% below our estimate (£98.5m) at the mid-point.
FY19 revenue guidance for ‘high single digit’  reported revenue growth is also below RBC/consensus estimate of +12%, which implies a low-mid single digit downgrade to consensus estimates. Wholesale growth is expected to remain mid-teens, with e-commerce +15-20%, whilst physical retail stores are likely to remain under pressure. Operating efficiency gains should help the business continue to drive operating leverage (20-50bps net) despite a lower than expected top line trajectory, and we understand early PBT guidance is at £110m which is 3% below our published estimate.
Net, the business has been impacted by one-offs in 4Q, with revenue guidance below current expectations which may put short term pressure on the stock in our view.

wayneJ @zho - will have a look at Paul's stuff - but given his timekeeping - will it be up today or tomorrow? :-)
Cabin Fever @wayneJA SuperDry trading top sounds like technical analyst's jargon.
BE11:47am

Superdry is in good shape, having showcased its business at its Capital Markets Day last Autumn, from a people, processes and future potential perspective. However, normalising retail LFLs and the potential disruption from pull-forward demand effects and the associated margin implications from inventory rebase could destabilise this trend near term.
Medium term, the internationalization opportunities that exist in North America and Asia underpinned by the brand’s universal appeal in the casual apparel space are compelling, although the path to sustainable margin improvements is not as obvious as we would like.
Balanced risk/reward limits our rating to Sector Perform with a GBP 19 price target. The stock trades at 12.9x cal FY19E P/E and 6.3x EV/EBITDA, at a discount to our
wider coverage, however reflecting the above  potential execution risks in our view.

Group FY sales +16% vs. CGEe +16.9%, with weakness in stores in Q4 (-6%) driven by weather;
online and wholesale remain strong. FY gross margin -200bp vs. CGe -130bp. US hit by landlord
disruption and is now expected to make a £3m loss vs. small profit previously. The company expects FY18E PBT £96.5m-£97.5m vs. CGe £98.1m and company’s previous consensus
range of £97.7m to £100.6m. Guiding to high single digit sales growth with moderate operating
margin expansion in FY19E vs. CGe +15.6% sales growth, so potentially greater downside to
FY19E PBT of £117m (113p). The shares were weak going into this, but we expect further
weakness today. Cal. 18 PE 14.5x.

BE11:57am

Q1 production of 287koz is only a modest miss vs. JPM (2% below), whilst total cash cost of $720/oz is 2% above. Q1 implies an annualised ~1.6Moz, or ~12% below the mid-pt of unchanged guidance of 1.30-1.35Moz (current JPM 1.31Moz), which implies a step-change in output over the balance of 2018. Profit from mining activity (EBITDA proxy) is $180m, 1% below JPM & underlying earnings of $58m is 7% below our estimate; EPS is tracking at ~17% of current Bloomberg consensus. Net cash increased to ~$737m vs. $717m at YE’17 which implies an annualised FCF yield ~1.1%, although the cash-flow performance was below our expectation (net cash $790m) which was a function of a receivables-driven working capital build of ~$49m (JPM $3m release).

BE11:57am

Whilst production & financials are weaker sequentially, they are largely “in line” with JPM. The positive is that production & cost guidance have both been maintained. Output (and costs) at Kibali also show an improving trend in what is generally the weakest period of the year (e.g. power) & RRS received a dividend from the JV ($11m). However, guidance implies a large step-up over the balance of the year which may put some pressure on near-term consensus estimates. Furthermore, cash flow was weak due to an unexpected increase in receivables (which doesn’t appear to be TVA driven) which now means a cumulative ~$62m in receivables outflows over the last two quarters.

BE11:58am

While acknowledging the miss during the quarter, we
maintain that the shortfall was driven by temporary factors (labour action) at the Tongon mine and the company is well-positioned to recover most of the lost output and meeting its production guidance for the full-year. Underlying performance of the core mines in Mali and the DRC (greater than 80% of attributable enterprise value) was in-line/ahead of expectations and their grades are expected to rise throughout the year in-line with the mine plan, which would drive volumes higher/costs lower. Following today's pull-back, shares are now trading on an EV/Reserve&Resource value of 0.18x as compared to a 10-year average of 0.19x and an average of 0.25x over the LTM.
